@Fokko, I fixed the failing test. But I'm not sure why kubernetis tests failed. They passed during the previous build, the only change I did - fixed long line.

> `Δ = absolute <relative> (impact)`, `ø = not affected`, `? = missing data`
> Powered by [Codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/3509?src=pr&el=footer). Last update [3245d17...8f5cca2](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/3509?src=pr&el=lastupdated). Read the [comment docs](https://docs.codecov.io/docs/pull-request-comments).
@Fokko, it is green now
@kaxil feel free to merge if it looks good to you as well, thank you for your help!

After taking all of your comments into consideration, I have updated it to include the following.
- Airflow will log that it believes there is no DAG in a file, once per DagBag. This is to not spam users with a ton of skip messages.
- I've updated docs mentioning in two places how Airflow's logic works, so it is much more apparent how it skips the files.
- If a single file does not contain "airflow" and "DAG" in a zip file, it will not return immediately. Thus allowing to load all DAGs from a .zip.

Let me know if there are any changes you'd like to see.
Thanks for your feedback!

[Continue to review full report at Codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/3505?src=pr&el=continue).
> **Legend** - [Click here to learn more](https://docs.codecov.io/docs/codecov-delta)
> `Δ = absolute <relative> (impact)`, `ø = not affected`, `? = missing data`
> Powered by [Codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/3505?src=pr&el=footer). Last update [ef3ead1...65778f5](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/3505?src=pr&el=lastupdated). Read the [comment docs](https://docs.codecov.io/docs/pull-request-comments).
@Fokko @imroc This LGTM. Perhaps we can also set an error if neither is set (if it's not handled somewhere else)? Thank you for finding this @imroc!

This seems to me like an outrageous amount of changes (17 files, 295 lines) for a progress bar on a cli command. Can you describe the high level approach?

I'm guessing the goal of wiring this `verbose` flag around to silence logging? First do we need to silence logging? And if we do can we do that through the logging handler, maybe log to a file and print the progress bar?

If the flag suppresses logging in favor of [only] a bar I'm not sure if I'd use it as I'd loose touch on what is currently happening. Simply printing `5 out of 9 dag runs finished\n 455 out of 512 tasks successful` at every backfill heartbeat serves pretty much the same purpose without all this extra logic and hiding other potentially useful details.
qq: What authentication method did you use? In what situation that `current_user` has `user` attribute but it is `None`?
is the zip file in test folder still needed?

@TrevorEdwards @Noremac201 The long term solution is most likely the DAGFetcher abstraction, which would know a little better how to find DAGs, either by using a manifest (Basically, you add the relevant file to a list) or another litmus test for the existence of a DAG. By making this configurable, we could allow users to define what is right for their infrastructure, with a default out of the box to the old behaviour.

@feng-tao I believe so, there's currently a unit test that uses it to test getting a DAG from inside of a zip file. All I did was add another .py in the .zip which doesn't contain "airflow" or "DAG" to make sure it doesn't skip DAGs like before.

@mistercrunch the problem I have is that subprocesses are logging to stdout, which pollutes the progress bar so I decided to silence them. I was able to redirect the logging in the main process tho.

Sounds like we still want to logs from subprocesses, I will look into a way to redirect logs from subprocesses to main process.

@youngyjd Used all default setting, authentication is turned off. DefaultUser was used. If my users table is empty the [default_login doesn't seem to be able to load the user](https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/blob/master/airflow/default_login.py#L73-L75). FYI I'm testing using the legacy UI.
Also, can you update the PR title as well to match your commit title?
Thanks, @imroc for your contribution and @dimberman  for reviewing it.
@NielsZeilemaker You also need to add it over here: https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/blob/master/docs/code.rst
Thanks for explanation!
@dimberman PTAL

Code-wise this looks fine to me. You could test this by adding a travis step that copies the kubeconfig to an arbitrary folder and then running a test that points to that arbitrary kubeconfig. Also it looks like your travis build is failing (might need to rebase)
@Noremac201 Can you add the test @dimberman is suggesting? Once that is done I am happy to merge this.
Can you squash your commits into a single commit?

@jgao54 PTAL
Thanks for merging! :-)

@artwr ty for the opinion, sry for getting back so late--was occupied by some internal work. I see this is basically [parameterized method](https://refactoring.guru/parameterize-method) versus [Explicit Methods](https://refactoring.guru/replace-parameter-with-explicit-methods). Given that new state won't be frequently added and the if/else block will be pretty big, I'm slightly leaning towards keeping explicit methods. As before, if you insist I can switch back.

CC @saguziel for some more opinion

I am new to Airflow so please correct me if I am wrong.
It seems to me a weird choice to give the triggered dag a dag_id that is dependent on now instead of the passed execution_date. And I suspect this causes troubles with backfills. 

Suppose I have a daily dag_1 that starts at midnight and when it's done it triggers a dag_2. 
Suppose that execution date of dag_1 is 2018-06-11 and that the same date is passed to dag_2.
dag_1 will have a run_id like "scheduled__2018-06-18T00:00:00"
I would expect dag_2 to have a dag_id like: "trig__2018-06-18T00:00:00"

If the dag_2 run_id is computed using now the name of dag_2 run_id could be very different (if dag_2 takes hours to complete or if we are doing a backfill of dag_1).

Thanks for reading this and please tell me if I am making wrong assumptions here.

For the record, I now notice an abstract `CheckOperator` already exists which is more generic. In light of this, I'm going to look to implement a `jdbc_check_operator.py` and possibly add some new functionality to the `check_operator.py` for `xcom`'ing rows.

@JacobHayes You're right!
It seems that the 'REPLACE INTO' syntax is supported for [MySQL](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/replace.html) and [SQLite](http://www.sqlitetutorial.net/sqlite-replace-statement/), but looks slightly different for other engines.

I'm a bit unhappy about introducing the `replace=` parameter just for `mysql_hook.insert_rows`, as this seems to be a useful feature for all engines, and in doing it just for one engine, we would also copy over a lot of generic code from `dbapi_hook` to the mysql-specific implementation (with the possibly happening as for other implementations as well as soon we start supporting that feature for these). Similar applies to a separate `replace_rows` method.

After some deeper look into the code, one way to solve that would be splitting out the sql string generation process into two separate methods (one for insert and one for replace, with the latter raising `NotImplementedError` in `dbapi_hook`), and overiding those in the engine specific classes. I'll file a PR later, please have a look then :-)
@sekikn The changes in the file does not correlate with the Jira

@r39132 Thanks for taking this Sid :) I think it's correlate. Let me elaborate.

For now, the variable `devel_all` in setup.py is defined as follows:

```
devel_all = (sendgrid + ... + azure_data_lake, atlas)
```

So, `devel_all` is a tuple of lists, which value is `(['sendgrid>=5.2.0', ..., 'azure-datalake-store==0.0.19'], ['atlasclient>=0.1.2'])`.

And these lines

```
if PY3:
    devel_ci = [package for package in devel_all if package not in
                ['snakebite>=2.7.8', 'snakebite[kerberos]>=2.7.8']]
```

intends to remove snakebite from a **flat** list, but `devel_all` is nested as described above, so this filtering doesn't work. As a result, `devel_ci` equals `devel_all`.

You can see that snakebite is not installed on Python3 here:
https://travis-ci.org/apache/incubator-airflow/jobs/394182327

while it's installed without this fix:
https://travis-ci.org/apache/incubator-airflow/jobs/394000076

Ah. I missed that `,`

Great catch!! +1
ping :D

hey @gauthiermartin , feel free to put the comment in the doc. But the doc is a little outdated as we discuss some of the implementations details in the pr as well as through email alias.

We can write it out to check. The only value which changes is the tasks for which to change state at the end. You can keep the explicit methods as wrapper, but I still think we should maintain the shared logic in a single place.

```python

@provide_session
def set_dag_run_state(dag, execution_date, to_state, commit=False, session=None):
    """
    """
    res = []

    if not dag or not execution_date:
        return res

    # Mark the dag run to the new state.
    if commit:
        DR = DagRun
        dr = session.query(DR).filter(
            DR.dag_id == dag.dag_id,
            DR.execution_date == execution_date
        ).one()
        dr.state = to_state
        dr.end_date = timezone.utcnow()
        session.commit()

    # Mark all task instances of the dag run to the new state.
    if to_state != State.FAILED:
        tasks_to_change = dag.tasks
    # Only set running to failed.
    else:
        TI = TaskInstance
        task_ids = [task.task_id for task in dag.tasks]
        tis = session.query(TI).filter(
            TI.dag_id == dag.dag_id,
            TI.execution_date == execution_date,
            TI.task_id.in_(task_ids)).filter(TI.state == State.RUNNING)
        task_ids_of_running_tis = set([ti.task_id for ti in tis])
        tasks_to_change = [
            task for task in dag.tasks 
            if task.task_id in task_ids_of_running_tis
        ]
    for task in tasks_to_change:
        task.dag = dag
        new_state = set_state(task=task, execution_date=execution_date,
                              state=to_state, commit=commit)
        res.extend(new_state)

    return res
    

def set_dag_run_state_to_success(dag, execution_date, commit=False, session=None):
    set_dag_run_state(dag, execution_date, to_state=State.SUCCESS, commit=commit, session=session)

def set_dag_run_state_to_failed(dag, execution_date, commit=False, session=None):
    set_dag_run_state(dag, execution_date, to_state=State.FAILED, commit=commit, session=session)

def set_dag_run_state_to_running(dag, execution_date, commit=False, session=None):
    set_dag_run_state(dag, execution_date, to_state=State.RUNNING, commit=commit, session=session)

```

@feng-tao are you referring to [this line](https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/3197/files#diff-5aeaca39c3e310ff9883f8ac4d506d1dR141) syncing roles? From my limited understanding of front end stuff, the apps actually serving traffic live in [the gunicron workers](https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/blob/master/airflow/bin/cli.py#L882). After the subprocess are created, [cached_app() will be called to create one app per subprocess](https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/blob/master/airflow/bin/cli.py#L832). Since security_manager.sync_roles() lives in create_app(), we should be able to resync the roles/perms everytime we restart the subprocess( not the webserver). Meanwhile, [the workers will be restarted every web_server_worker_timeout](https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/blob/master/airflow/bin/cli.py#L812), thus we can refresh both DagBag and roles/perms w/o restarting the master webserver process.

If what I stated is just misunderstanding, I would still strongly suggest we find a way to remove this line--either extract only the needed logic or start the subprocess earlier or something like that. The current approach scales very bad and does not make any sense to me( we're waiting for 2 complete app constructions including 2 single process DagBag parsing before the webserver can serve traffic, at least with the current scale of Airbnb means ~28mins to start a webserver--for around 2k DAG files including some complicated framework DAG files).
Actually, `dbapi.run` and `dbapi.insert_rows` already share a lot of code, with the only part missing being the `commit_every` feature. So it would make much more sense to abstract that :-)

An update on this PR:

- Hive is added to `$PATH` on the [base image](https://github.com/gerardo/incubator-airflow-ci) now instead of the docker-compose file. Thanks @Noremac201 for reporting this out.
- A recently merged PR introduced Cassandra as a dependency. It was really simple to add a new Casandra service on docker-compose file and have the default `CassandraHook` point to the `cassandra` host 😄 
- I'm also building [my branch on TravisCI](https://travis-ci.com/gerardo/incubator-airflow/), which is passing. Through this, I found a problem with the pip cache under the TravisCI Apache org. The current pip cache needs to be deleted once as part of merging this PR. The `mysqlclient` library there was built against the travisci host (ubuntu trusty), but the docker-compose version is running ubuntu xenial (a more recent version). That causes the [current build failures in this branch](https://travis-ci.org/apache/incubator-airflow/builds/394426183).

If someone could delete the cache, that would be great (I guess I could just `rm -rf ~/.cache/pip` from the travisci script, push that change, wait for it to run, then remove it)
